titleStmt.title: From the tips of his
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was probably written between 1853 and 1855, while Whitman was working on the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. Versions of these cancelled and fragmentary lines were used in the first poem in that edition, eventually titled "Song of Myself."

note.p: Versions of these lines appeared in what ultimately came to be section 39 of "Song of Myself." In the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass, the lines read: "They descend in new forms from the tips of his fingers, / They are wafted with the odor of his body or breath . . . . they fly out of the glance of his eyes (1855, p. 44).

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Free cider and Long Island character
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839â€“1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original item.

This manuscript leaf originally formed part of a larger notebook. We have made composite images that show the continuation of the text on this leaf with text on the notebook leaf from which it was cut, and the manuscripts have been transcribed in separate files.

revisionDesc.change: edited note to reflect nb connection, updated pbs

body.ab: From the tips of his fingers
from the breaths of his lungs
from the sparkle of his eyes,
from the odor of his body
